intro: Blepharochilum sladeanum, commonly known as Slade's beardtongue, is a herbaceous perennial native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the plant family Plantaginaceae and is characterized by its tall, slender stems and clusters of purple or pink flowers. The plant has lance-shaped leaves that are arranged oppositely along the stem. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or open fields. Its bloom period typically occurs in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
